ticket.title: Form authenticity token in form tag should be set to display:inline
ticket.original-body:
When a form is rendered using `form_tag` or `form_for`, the form authenticity token is of course placed right after the `<form>` tag automatically. While this is a hidden field so it won't show up, it is wrapped in a div tag that does not have `display: inline` set on it. This means that if you want your form to be inline, you have to set something like
form div { display: inline }
or else the form will have a line break where the form authenticity token hidden field is. However, because [there's no way to target this exactly](https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/2044-patch-to-add-html-options-to-the-div-that-wraps-the-authenticity_token-input-field), if you happen to have any other divs in your form for whatever reason, you'll have to give those classes or something so you can override the `display: inline` in your CSS.
I don't actually know why the hidden field is wrapped in a div, maybe there's some reason, but I've made a patch that sets this div to `display: inline`.
ticket.latest-body:
When a form is rendered using `form_tag` or `form_for`, the form authenticity token is of course placed right after the `<form>` tag automatically. While this is a hidden field so it won't show up, it is wrapped in a div tag that does not have `display: inline` set on it. This means that if you want your form to be inline, you have to set something like
form div { display: inline }
or else the form will have a line break where the form authenticity token hidden field is. However, because [there's no way to target this exactly](https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/2044-patch-to-add-html-options-to-the-div-that-wraps-the-authenticity_token-input-field), if you happen to have any other divs in your form for whatever reason, you'll have to give those classes or something so you can override the `display: inline` in your CSS.
I don't actually know why the hidden field is wrapped in a div, maybe there's some reason, but I've made a patch that sets this div to `display: inline`.
ticket.original-body-html:
When a form is rendered using form_tag or form_for, the form authenticity token is of course placed right after the tag automatically. While this is a hidden field so it won't show up, it is wrapped in a div tag that does not have `display: inline` set on it. This means that if you want your form to be inline, you have to set something like

form div { display: inline }

or else the form will have a line break where the form authenticity token hidden field is. However, because there's no way to target this exactly, if you happen to have any other divs in your form for whatever reason, you'll have to give those classes or something so you can override the display: inline in your CSS.

I don't actually know why the hidden field is wrapped in a div, maybe there's some reason, but I've made a patch that sets this div to display: inline.

version.body:
When a form is rendered using `form_tag` or `form_for`, the form authenticity token is of course placed right after the `<form>` tag automatically. While this is a hidden field so it won't show up, it is wrapped in a div tag that does not have `display: inline` set on it. This means that if you want your form to be inline, you have to set something like
form div { display: inline }
or else the form will have a line break where the form authenticity token hidden field is. However, because [there's no way to target this exactly](https://rails.lighthouseapp.com/projects/8994/tickets/2044-patch-to-add-html-options-to-the-div-that-wraps-the-authenticity_token-input-field), if you happen to have any other divs in your form for whatever reason, you'll have to give those classes or something so you can override the `display: inline` in your CSS.
I don't actually know why the hidden field is wrapped in a div, maybe there's some reason, but I've made a patch that sets this div to `display: inline`.
version.body-html:
When a form is rendered using form_tag or form_for, the form authenticity token is of course placed right after the <form> tag automatically. While this is a hidden field so it won't show up, it is wrapped in a div tag that does not have display: inline set on it. This means that if you want your form to be inline, you have to set something like

form div { display: inline }

or else the form will have a line break where the form authenticity token hidden field is. However, because there's no way to target this exactly, if you happen to have any other divs in your form for whatever reason, you'll have to give those classes or something so you can override the display: inline in your CSS.

I don't actually know why the hidden field is wrapped in a div, maybe there's some reason, but I've made a patch that sets this div to display: inline.
version.title: Form authenticity token in form tag should be set to display:inline

version.title: Form authenticity token in form tag should be set to display:inline

version.body:
This is marked resolved, but we recently had an issue with the patch: the inline style of "display:inline" in the HTML cannot be overridden by a stylesheet and is creating issues for us in Safari. It seems incorrect for Rails to be injecting a block level element inside a form just to hold a hidden input, but if for some reason this is absolutely necessary, it seems it would be preferable to set the style to "display:none".
Anyone agree that a better solution should be implemented? If so, I wouldn't mind creating a new patch.
version.body-html:
This is marked resolved, but we recently had an issue with the patch: the inline style of "display:inline" in the HTML cannot be overridden by a stylesheet and is creating issues for us in Safari. It seems incorrect for Rails to be injecting a block level element inside a form just to hold a hidden input, but if for some reason this is absolutely necessary, it seems it would be preferable to set the style to "display:none".

Anyone agree that a better solution should be implemented? If so, I wouldn't mind creating a new patch.
version.title: Form authenticity token in form tag should be set to display:inline

version.body: Now that I think about it some more, that makes more sense. At first I was concerned that hiding the hidden fields using CSS would cause the token to not be submitted along with the form, but I just tested setting the div to "display: none" like you just said, and I didn't get an InvalidAuthenticityToken error or anything like that, so obviously it still works. So that sounds good to me.
version.body-html: Now that I think about it some more, that makes more sense. At first I was concerned that hiding the hidden fields using CSS would cause the token to not be submitted along with the form, but I just tested setting the div to "display: none" like you just said, and I didn't get an InvalidAuthenticityToken error or anything like that, so obviously it still works. So that sounds good to me.
version.title: Form authenticity token in form tag should be set to display:inline

version.body: As to being able to override it using a stylesheet, I can't see a use case for it, but looks like you have one?
version.body-html: As to being able to override it using a stylesheet, I can't see a use case for it, but looks like you have one?
version.title: Form authenticity token in form tag should be set to display:inline

version.body: Cool. Regarding the CSS overriding--was just mentioning that it wouldn't work for setting it to display:none since it had the inline style set on the tag (which takes precedence over anything else).
version.body-html: Cool. Regarding the CSS overriding--was just mentioning that it wouldn't work for setting it to display:none since it had the inline style set on the tag (which takes precedence over anything else).
